content: The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Act", excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Special rules apply to reduce the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, with special rules to reduce the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, with exceptions for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition and an ordering rule for discharged loans. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income. If a loan is partially discharged, the exclusion applies only to the amount exceeding the non-qualified principal residence indebtedness. Coordination amendments are made to section 108(a)(2) of the Code. The term 'principal residence' has the same meaning as in section 121. Coordination amendments are made to section 108(a)(2) of the Code, stating that the principal residence exclusion takes precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. The amendments made by this section apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007, with an insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. The amendment applies to amounts paid after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation, including deriving 80 percent or more of gross income from tenant-stockholders or having 80 percent or more of property square footage used by them. The cooperative housing corporation must meet certain criteria to qualify, including deriving income from tenant-stockholders, having 80% or more of property used by them, and ensuring that most expenditures are for property-related purposes. The cooperative housing corporation must meet specific criteria to qualify, including having 90% or more of expenditures for property-related purposes. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section, SEC. 139B, which excludes benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of any member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization, gross income shall not include qualified State and local tax benefits or qualified payments. Expenses incurred in connection with services as a member will be taken into account for deductions. Expenses incurred by a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization in connection with services will be considered for deductions only if they exceed any qualified payment excluded from gross income. The term "qualified state and local tax benefit" refers to any reduction or rebate of specified taxes provided by a State or political division. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to tax reductions or rebates provided by a State or political division for services performed as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization. A 'qualified payment' is any payment provided by a State or political division for services as a member of such an organization. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to tax reductions or rebates provided by a State or political division for services performed as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization. A qualified payment is any payment provided by a State or political division for services as a member of such an organization, with an applicable dollar limitation of $30 per month for each month of service. The term 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' refers to a volunteer organization that provides firefighting or emergency medical services and is required by a State or political subdivision to do so. This section does not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. The section pertains to qualified volunteer emergency response organizations mandated by a State or political subdivision to provide firefighting or emergency medical services. It does not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Subclause (I) of section 42(i)(3)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended regarding student housing eligible for low-income housing credit. SEC. 6 clarifies that single parents and their children can qualify for low-income housing credit if they are not dependents of another individual. The amendment in section 7 applies to housing credit amounts allocated and buildings placed in service before or after the enactment date. It also addresses the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion on post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The amendment allows surviving spouses to qualify for a higher capital gains exclusion of $500,000 if they sell property within 2 years of their spouse's death. The amendment allows surviving spouses to qualify for a higher capital gains exclusion of $250,000 if they sell property within 2 years of their spouse's death, effective for sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. Modification of penalty for failure to file partnership returns; limitation on disclosure. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is raised from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to certain individuals is also amended. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is raised from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to certain individuals is also amended to exclude certain taxpayer identity information in specific cases. The amendment excludes taxpayer identity information of individuals not related to the entity or inspection. Effective date is upon enactment. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns. Penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 includes a penalty for late filing or incomplete information, with a maximum penalty of 12 months unless reasonable cause is shown. The penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 is determined by the number of shareholders in the corporation, with a maximum penalty of 12 months. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation. The penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns is based on the number of shareholders in the corporation, with a maximum penalty of 12 months. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation and deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns is based on the number of shareholders, with a maximum penalty of 12 months. The amendments in this section apply to returns after the enactment date. The percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points. The percentage under subparagraph (B) of section 401(1) of the Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005 is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
